item.title: Ticket #15533 (wp_get_nav_menu_items order doesn't work) updated
item.dc:creator: scribu
item.description: Description changed

item.title: Ticket #15533 (wp_get_nav_menu_items order doesn't work) created
item.dc:creator: markoheijnen
item.description:
Argument order doesn't work when output is ARRAY_A since on the end of function wp_get_nav_menu_items there is a usort on the $items array what will be returned.

Since out ARRAY_A is the default output this can give strange behaviour.

The code that gives the problem: 

	if ( ARRAY_A == $args['output'] ) {
		$GLOBALS['_menu_item_sort_prop'] = $args['output_key'];
		usort($items, '_sort_nav_menu_items');
		$i = 1;
		foreach( $items as $k => $item ) {
			$items[$k]->$args['output_key'] = $i++;
		}
	}

item.dc:creator: nacin
item.description: Owner, Status, Milestone changed

item.title: Ticket #15532 (Inserting links doesn't work when editing in full screen) created
item.dc:creator: RanYanivHartstein
item.description:
When using the Visual Editor in full screen mode, the Insert Links pop up is not available - it gets hidden behind the editor so it looks like nothing happens when you click it, but it shows up when you exit full screen.

To reproduce this, edit any post in the Visual Editor in full screen mode, select some text and click on the Insert Link button in the tool bar. Nothing will apear to happen. Then, exit full screen mode, and you'll see the Insert Link pop up.

I was able to reproduce this in Firefox 3.6 and Chrome 7 on a mac.

item.title: Ticket #14648 (Flash Uploader security error in IDN domains) updated
item.dc:creator: dovydas
item.description:
Cc changed

Here is the WORKAROUND that helped me:

  1. Download. I have downloaded SWFUploader 2.2.0.1 (from here: ​http://code.google.com/p/swfupload/downloads/detail?name=SWFUpload%20v2.2.0.1%20Core.zip) and I have extracted zip archive.
  1. Backup. In the Wordpress directory wp-includes/js/swfupload/ I have renamed files swfupload.swf and swfupload.js to swfupload.swf.old and swfupload.js.old. Also I have renamed all *.js files in wp-includes/js/swfupload/plugins/ directory to *.js.old.
  1. Replace. Then I have copied new files swfupload.js and swfupload.swf to wp-includes/js/swfupload/ directory. Also I have copied all *.js files from SWFUploader 2.2.0.1 package /plugins/ directory to wp-includes/js/swfupload/plugins/ directory.

Flash uploader works for my IDN site now'''

Please note, hat you have to clear your browser cache. I thought it didn't work at first. I still received "security error". But then I tried a different browser with a clear cache and all of sudden I get my files uploaded!

Thank you dkwo for the tip.

item.title: Ticket #15447 (Cache Post Thumbnails) updated
item.dc:creator: TheDeadMedic
item.description:
Perhaps caching should also depend on the query arg 'cache_results', and possibly a new query arg 'update_post_thumbnail_cache' (to match the pattern of the existing 'update_post_term_cache' and 'update_post_meta_cache' args)?

So by default (if thumbnail feature supported), thumbnails are cached for the main query (i.e. the request), but a theme author has the option to cache/not cache for their own loop(s)?

item.title: Ticket #12891 (Advanced multi-taxonomy WP_Query()s) updated
item.dc:creator: scribu
item.description:
The logic behind [16526] is that WP_Query should not care about URL decoding.

Thus,

if you go to an URL like /category/foo+bar/ it will be interpreted as foo AND bar

but if you call get_posts('category_name=Foo Bar'), it will look for foo-bar

item.dc:creator: F J Kaiser
item.description: Not really. You can just override the _default_wp_die_handler() function. Like with wp_login.php & wp_admin/install.php most people just need to override the .css files, which is only possible if you redefine the wp_admin_css function or in this case the complete _default_wp_die_handler function. Better & easier would be to just have filters for the .css files.

item.dc:creator: johnbillion
item.description:
Westi grepped the plugin repo this morning and found that not one single plugin uses the 'adminmenu' hook. This means there is no issue with regard to this hook moving.

What else could potentially break in plugins if this patch was applied? JS? CSS?

item.title: Ticket #14876 (wp_get_sidebars_widgets() assumes that widgets are enabled) reopened
item.dc:creator: nacin
item.description:
Turns out that is_active_widget() would be called before widgets_init, inside the default widget constructors. Thus, no sidebars would be registered, and we get false returned.

Reverting [15994] for now. This was noticed when trying to add a filter to #15493.

For another ticket, I guess: Noticing that these aren't translatable, in either table. Probably not a regression, but shouldn't this be %1$s %2$s with a translator's comment of Translators: %1 first name, %2 last name, for languages that flip these? I think that would also require a new sorting algorithm as well.

item.title: 15529.patch attached to Ticket #15529

item.title: Ticket #15529 (Add class name to first menu item in wp_nav_menu()) created
item.dc:creator: johnbillion
item.description:
If the theme displays the output of wp_nav_menu() horizontally and wants to put a separator between menu items, then usually something like a left border is used.

To remove this separator from the left hand side of the menu, the first item will often have the border or background image removed by using the ':first-child' CSS pseudo class. This is all well and good but the ':first-child' selector isn't supported in IE6.

If we added a 'first-child' or 'first-menu-item' class to the first menu item then it'd be easier for themers to use this property and maintain support for IE6.

Thoughts?

item.title: Ticket #14084 (Custom taxonomy count includes draft & trashed posts) updated
item.dc:creator: mfields
item.description:
I have witnessed the behavior that lumpysimon has reported.

If the 'update_count_callback' argument is not defined when a custom taxonomy is registered it's value is set to empty and the post count will not be updated when post_status is changed, only when published. However, if a custom taxonomy's 'update_count_callback' argument is set to '_update_post_term_count', the count will be updated when post_status is changed from a value of 'publish', 'draft' or 'pending' to a value of 'publish', 'draft' or 'pending'.

I'm not sure whether or not it is a good idea to suggest that users set the value of 'update_count_callback' to a function marked as private in core. Would it be better to have register_taxonomy() set this function for the user instead of giving it an empty value?

In my tests I never witnessed the count being updated when a post's status was changed to or from 'trash'. I believe this to be a bug.

item.title: Ticket #14642 (Support Facebook's HipHop) updated
item.dc:creator: jane

item.title: Ticket #15527 (Add new comment from post editor) created
item.dc:creator: jane
item.description: In the post editor, there is a Discussion box with selectors for allowing comments/pings, and a Comments box that actually lists the comments on the post/page and allows moderation. A use case I come across occasionally is that someone wants to add a comment to their own post, but currently they have to go to the live site to do so. It would a good thing to add a little 'Add new comment' link at the top of the Comments box that would open the comment form (a la clicking Reply).

item.title: Ticket #12891 (Advanced multi-taxonomy WP_Query()s) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
$q['category_name'] = implode('/', array_map('sanitize_title', explode('/', $q['category_name'])));

The sanitize_title() allowed full names to be passed.The intention was for only slugs to be passed, but the code allowed full names to work.

item.title: Ticket #15525 (Use network/update-core.php and redirect to /network/ if it's necessary) updated
item.dc:creator: nacin
item.description:
That looks good.

Thinking we should do an audit for files that should redirect to /network/ when running multisite. Otherwise is_network_admin() would return false and plugins (and potentially core) may get confused.

This file would be one of them. It's a simple is_multisite() && ! is_network_admin() check.

item.title: Ticket #15484 (jQuery UI fragmentation breaks plugins) updated
item.dc:creator: scribu
item.description: Milestone changed

item.title: Ticket #15484 (jQuery UI fragmentation breaks plugins) closed
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
wontfix:

Turns out that the new jQuery UI widget factory has some breaking changes (according to jQuery UI 1.8 changelog), which makes breaking it out into its own file reasonable. So for real back-compat, we'd have to bundle an old version of jQuery UI (and an old version of jQuery). Not realistic. Plugins will just have to be updated.

I'll make an announcement on wpdevel.

item.title: Ticket #15521 (Network / Site Admin toggle is hard to find) updated
item.dc:creator: nacin
item.description:
Replying to filosofo:

That responds to a couple of my points, but not:

  • The Updates notifications are under Dashboard [In other words, there's the tacit suggestion that this is a nexus of global activity]

Updates should not appear here in multisite. If it hasn't been removed yet, there's a patch somewhere to do it.

  • "Dashboard" is a global notion and appears in both modes

Two separate dashboards, though. So it's not a global notion.

  • The Dashboard menu has a link to the meta-site "My Sites" page

Which is a horrible spot for it :-)

  • All other admin links appear in the left menu
  • The user's profile link (also in the upper right where the network admin link is) is duplicated in the left menu under Users.

Both fair points, but I would argue that this is unique.

In response, I would argue that it is more consistent:

  • all other navigational links appear in the left navigational menu
  • Dashboard is global and already has site-management stuff

It doesn't have site management stuff. It's just a really bad spot for My Sites as there isn't really a better spot for it (yet).

item.title: Ticket #15522 (register_nav_menus not working) created
item.dc:creator: christian_gnoth
item.description:
I am using in my theme: 

  if ( function_exists( 'register_nav_menus' ) )
  {
    register_nav_menus(
            array(
                'header-menu' => 'Header Menu',
                'extra-menu' => 'Extra Menu'
                 )
    );
  }

this two locations are not displayed in the wp admin menu srea. there is no locations box at all - also no option to activate/deactivate it.

item.title: Ticket #15521 (Network / Site Admin toggle is hard to find) updated
item.dc:creator: filosofo
item.description:
That responds to a couple of my points, but not:

  • The Updates notifications are under Dashboard [In other words, there's the tacit suggestion that this is a nexus of global activity]
  • "Dashboard" is a global notion and appears in both modes
  • The Dashboard menu has a link to the meta-site "My Sites" page
  • All other admin links appear in the left menu
  • The user's profile link (also in the upper right where the network admin link is) is duplicated in the left menu under Users.

In response, I would argue that it is more consistent:

  • all other navigational links appear in the left navigational menu
  • Dashboard is global and already has site-management stuff

item.title: Ticket #15521 (Network / Site Admin toggle is hard to find) created
item.dc:creator: filosofo
item.description:
The link should also appear under Dashboard in the left navigational menu:

  • It's not immediately obvious where it is, either based on past WP experience or other admin navigation clues.
  • The old Super Admin menu was up in the same area
  • The Updates notifications are under Dashboard
  • "Dashboard" is a global notion and appears in both modes
  • The Dashboard menu has a link to the meta-site "My Sites" page
  • All other admin links appear in the left menu
  • The user's profile link (also in the upper right where the network admin link is) is duplicated in the left menu under Users.

Screenshot shows what the patch does for each mode.

item.title: Ticket #15520 (Break date/time into a separate column in Comments views) created
item.dc:creator: markel
item.description:
Now that column sorting is in, it makes sense to break the date and time a comment was made into a separate column in the Comments view so they can be sorted chronologically.

Currently, the time is part of the content column, which can be confusing as if someone sorts by that column it becomes an alphabetical sort.

item.title: Ticket #15519 (Allow pure information and not only links in Administration Bar) created
item.dc:creator: neoxx
item.description:
Derived from ticket #14772

Purpose:

Extend the Admin Bar API in a way to allow pure information (arbitrary HTML) which is not wrapped in links.

Reasons:

  • Integrate plain texts in the Admin Bar by plugins
  • Create valid XHTML with all HTML-elements (e.g. 'bigger' components like the search bar in a <div>) which fit inside of a <li>

Two possibilites:

  • empty href => no_link_possible.diff
  • hooks in quicklinks-list and/or between links-list and search-bar ?> admin_bar_inner_hooks.diff

item.title: exit-after-redirects.15518.diff attached to Ticket #15518
item.dc:creator: filosofo

item.title: Ticket #15518 (Exit After wp_redirect) created
item.dc:creator: filosofo
item.description:
We should end code execution after calling wp_redirect, except in those rare cases where code execution is meant to occur after sending the headers, such as in cron and plugin activation check.

Otherwise, we risk unexpected behavior and unseen results in some cases.

item.title: Ticket #15517 ('postid' field in metaWeblog.getRecentPosts should be a string) created
item.dc:creator: mrroundhill
item.description:
In 3.1, the xml-rpc metaWeblog.getRecentPosts call is returning the 'postid' field as an integer when it should be a string:

​http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa905674.aspx

Clients such as the WordPress for iPhone app can't handle the different type and force closes when refreshing the posts tab.

item.title: Ticket #15485 (Inserting links is not working in Internet explorer 7/8) updated
item.dc:creator: designsimply
item.description:
Inserting links now works in IE8. Beautiful!

I still can't get it to work in IE7 though.

Test results with r16504, SCRIPT_DEBUG = true and IE7: ​http://screencast.com/t/EgQFsrbJ

On page load, I see this error in IE7: 

Line: 2
Char: 996
Error: Expected identifier, string or number
Code: 0
URL: http://design5279.com/trunk/wp-admin/post-new.php

When I highlight text and click the link icon, I see this error in IE7: 

Line: 2
Char: 4438
Error: 'undefined' is null or not an object
Code: 0
URL: http://design5279.com/trunk/wp-admin/post-new.php

Based on the fact that I see js errors on page load, I think this may be a more general TinyMCE or js problem, but I'm not sure. Should I open a new trac ticket for the js errors shown above?

item.title: Ticket #15516 (Candidates for new template functions based on code in Twenty Ten) updated
item.dc:creator: nacin
item.description:
Keywords, Milestone changed

Been thinking about a replacement for max_mum_pages for a while. Unfortunately, we use 'paged' in the context of page > 2, not total pages > 2. Would be interested to make new functions though.

item.title: Ticket #15516 (Candidates for new template functions based on code in Twenty Ten) updated
item.dc:creator: johnbillion
item.description:
In loop.php we have: 

if ( $wp_query->max_num_pages > 1 )

It's not nice using the $wp_query object directly so let's put it in a function. posts_paged() would keep it consistent with comments_paged() suggested above. 

if ( posts_paged() )

Much nicer.

item.title: Ticket #15516 (Candidates for new template functions based on code in Twenty Ten) updated
item.dc:creator: johnbillion
item.description:
Version changed

First up in comments.php we have: 

if ( get_comment_pages_count() > 1 && get_option( 'page_comments' ) )

This is used twice and would be ideal as a function named comments_paged() instead, giving us: 

if ( comments_paged() )

item.title: Ticket #15515 (content_save_pre et al don't supply context) created
item.dc:creator: johnbillion
item.description:
All of the {field}_save_pre filters don't provide any additional parameters with context. The {field}_edit_pre (when editing) and post_{field} (when displaying) filters pass the $post_id variable as a second parameter. The {field}_save_pre filter is the odd one out.

Currently if a plugin uses (for example) the content_save_pre filter and needs to know anything about the post (eg. the post type) then it has to use the global $post object directly. It works, but it's not ideal.

Can we add some context to these hooks? All they need is a second parameter containing the $post_id variable to bring them in line with the other field filters.

item.title: Ticket #15505 (Excerpt is being double-escaped) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: (In [16502]) Don't esc_textarea() in meta boxes since the post object is already escaped. Props Viper007Bond. see #15505

item.title: Changeset [16502]: Don't esc_textarea() in meta boxes since the post object is already ...
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Don't esc_textarea() in meta boxes since the post object is already escaped. Props Viper007Bond. see #15505

item.title: Ticket #15505 (Excerpt is being double-escaped) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
The edit action in wp-admin/post.php fetches the post with get_post_to_edit(). This goes through the post sanitation and eventually calls format_to_edit() on the excerpt. This escaped post object is pass to all of the meta boxes. post_content, post_title, post_excerot, and post_password all get the format_to_edit() treatment.

Aside: Perhaps format_to_edit() should use esc_textarea().

item.title: Changeset [16501]: Could not bulk edit users in Network Admin due to reversed logic on ...
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Could not bulk edit users in Network Admin due to reversed logic on capability check, and incorrect action included for comparing to nonce. Props beaulebens

item.title: Ticket #15514 (Category/Tag Converter should include Post Format conversions) created
item.dc:creator: nacin
item.description:
The category/tag converter should include the ability to convert categories or tags to post formats.

The converter in general needs a pretty serious UI or code cleanup, so if anyone wants to own this, that would be awesome, and I will assist.

item.title: Ticket #15378 (Post formats should have built-in index pages) updated
item.dc:creator: nacin
item.description:
Here's what I'm thinking:

query var: two options, format, or the more conservative post_format. Not really a big deal as this would be hidden when pretty permalinks are enabled.

rewrite slug: obvious one would be format. That said:

I think I'd like to place a filter specifically on the rewrite slug. If that sounds unorthodox, keep in mind we have UI options on the permalinks page for category/tag base. *That* said, I'd actually entertain the idea of adding a UI option for format too though, assuming the active theme supports it. I know we shouldn't add options, but in this case, format is particularly ambiguous (more so than tag and category) and artificial, and I certainly see people wanting to change it to something that fits their style.

If that's backed by the rest of the core team, I'll code it up.

item.title: Ticket #13971 ("Wordpress" being turned into CamelCase "WordPress" breaks URLs) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis-de-Bernardy
item.description:
Priority, Severity, Milestone changed

Curious to know... I realize this is one of Matt's pet features, but this ticket, on the top of my head, has one of the highest number of votes in trac -- if not the highest. It's a f*cking outrage that it's getting so little attention by committers, on a project that is supposed to be driven by community members.

Could this ticket get any kind of traction before 3.1 gets released please? There are only so many alternatives:

  • A committer can remove this garbage and begone with it once and for all.
  • We can use extensive regexp'ing and fix any underlying issues that remain, at the cost of slowing WP down even more but with the benefit of keeping Matt happy.
  • A committer can close the ticket as wontfix, telling the community to have it up theirs.
  • Committers can leave the ticket open, telling the community to have it up theirs with sand and gravel.

item.title: Ticket #15513 (Home Page fails to use page template sometimes) created
item.dc:creator: filosofo
item.description:
If a page is the home page but not also the front page and it has a page template, the page template is ignored. This behavior is counter-intuitive:

  • When editing the home-page page, either normally or with quick edit, the page template is shown as being the template.
  • When acting as a front page, a page uses its page template if available.

item.title: Ticket #15512 (wp-admin colors-classic .alt .alternate error) created
item.dc:creator: webaware
item.description:
CSS classes .alt and .alternate specify row colour shading for alternate rows in tables. This fails in the classic (blue) admin colour scheme due to a missing comma in the CSS. 

.alt  /* <-- comma needed there, missing from CSS file */
.alternate {
	background-color: #edfbfc;
}

item.title: Ticket #12891 (Advanced multi-taxonomy WP_Query()s) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
Replying to scribu:

Replying to ryan:

How about a "no children" flag?

There already is one: 'include_children'. See the inline docs on get_tax_sql().

Yeah. See what I ended up using in the snippet above. Don't include children is one of the biggest requests so far. I think the child inclusion in 3.0 was a bit broken.

item.title: Ticket #15511 (Check for WP_Error earlier in edit_post) updated

item.title: Ticket #15511 (Check for WP_Error earlier in edit_post) created
item.dc:creator: alexdunae
item.description:
When working with custom post types where I hadn't assign the edit_others capabilities, _wp_translate_postdata was returning WP_Error.

edit_post checks for WP_Error, but not before assuming that the return value is actually array and triggering an ugly error.

item.title: Ticket #12891 (Advanced multi-taxonomy WP_Query()s) updated
item.dc:creator: scribu
item.description:
Replying to ryan:

And maybe if the tax_query has only one query in it we can forego requiring the outer array().

For simple queries, there still is the 'tax' => 'tag_1,tag_2' syntax.

item.title: Ticket #12891 (Advanced multi-taxonomy WP_Query()s) updated
item.dc:creator: scribu

There already is one: 'include_children'. See the inline docs on get_tax_sql().
